description: Borrowed from New Latin diathesis, from Ancient Greek διάθεσις (diáthesis, “state, condition”), from διατίθημι (diatíthēmi, “to arrange”).

entries.meaning: (medicine) A hereditary or constitutional predisposition to a disease or other disorder.
examples: Medical materialism seems indeed a good appellation for the too simple-minded system of thought which we are considering.  […]  All such mental over-tensions, it says, are, when you come to the bottom of the matter, mere affairs of diathesis (auto-intoxications most probably), due to the perverted action of various glands which physiology will yet discover.
